reviewText:
Update: If you like snooker, I highly recommend Snooker Nation Championship. It is an evolution of the snooker mode in Pool Nation FX with traditional visual aesthetics and enhanced physics that are tailored for snooker.

Original Review:
As someone who has been into pool and snooker for 20-odd years, I consider this game to be the most enjoyable virtual representation of the sports. If you want to know why Pool Nation FX is the best pool/snooker proposition on Steam, or any platform for that matter, you can read the following paragraphs.

To start with, let's see how it compares to the original Pool Nation game. While PNFX does not redefine the formula, it surely refines it. With the original game being quite successful, not many changes were needed anyway. The graphics are obviously prettier and there is a wider variety of locations, but the strongest points of PNFX compared to its predecessor are the improved table cloth speed, which feels more realistic, and the addition of snooker. The only real advantage that the original PN holds, are the lower system requirements.

But how does the game compare to the competition? There is Pure Pool, which is currently similarly priced. I had the chance to try that game having previously enjoyed its predecessor, Hustle Kings, on the PS3. I had relatively high expectations, but was pretty disappointed with it. Yes, it also has pretty graphics (not as pretty as PNFX), but the controls feel awkward, which makes controlling your shot power really hard, and the camera does not give you any freedom (basically, your view point is stuck to the cue, making aim-off play not a pleasant experience). All this is coupled with questionable physics, so I don't think anything else needs to be said about that game.
Then, there is Virtual Pool 4. To be fair, I have not played this game, as I tried downloading the demo, but after installing it, the game would just crash instantly after starting every single time. This was apparently a problem that occurred with the full game as well, but it should be fixed now. However, I didn't want to risk buying it. Speaking of such issues, various people have had crashing problems with PNFX, so neither game is immune to technical bugs. At least with PNFX, you can try the free version to see if it runs well for you. Technical stuff aside, from what I have seen and heard about VP4, it might hold some advantage in terms of physics simulation. The obvious disadvantage of VP4 though are the dated graphics. While gameplay is surely more important, playing in good-looking locations, which create a nice atmosphere, and having detailed tables and almost realistic balls, adds a lot to the overall experience for me. The other major drawback of VP4 is the pricing - currently it is twice as expensive as PNFX, but more importantly - if you want to continue playing it online, you have to pay a yearly subscription fee of 10 bucks. Compare this to the lifetime PNFX online pass, which costs 4 bucks. So, is it worth it to pay that much more for a slightly better simulation aspect? At least for me, the answer is No".

A major plus of PNFX is that the game continues to evolve. To be fair

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pool Nation FX is a Pool Simulation game that can be seen as an improvement to the original Pool Nation. I have a few things to say as to whether or not I would recommend the game or not.

Positives:

It looks great. However, having spent so much time in the original game, at this stage in time...1.6 hours... I prefer the look of the original game compared to Pool Nation FX. But perhaps the new look will grow on me over time.


More content. Pool Nation FX features an all-new career mode which is a big improvement from the original Pool Nation. It boasts many new locations and the 'play with skill to win' approach makes single-player pool a joy to play. Snooker is a great feature in Pool Nation. Me and a friend had an enjoyable time and like the other modes, are great.

Negatives:

I think the speed of the cloth could be adjusted. Perhaps there could be a slider added to the game, or a 'slow' or 'fast' speed option could be implemented. My friend and I were almost always complaining how the speed of the cloth could be better. It is fair, yes, but variety will always be appreciated.

Setting up a game with my friend had been slightly difficult as my friend had a microphone switched on in the lobby but I could not find a way to mute him so I had ended up turning the whole game down in the mixer.

Compared to Pool Nation, aiming and potting has become a lot harder, with or without aim assistance. I wish as I was taking my shot that I could look down the table even further. I have been using the middle mouse button to aim the cue more vertically to line up the cue ball better... however, it is still difficult.

I have been looking forward to Pool Nation FX for so long now that I cannot help but want any improvement the game can get. However, the game is great and I am very satisfied with my purchase. Also, thank you so much for the loyalty discount!

Thank you, Cherry Pop Games!

reviewText:
I looked at the recent reviews of this game and kinda perplexed why people downvoted the game for seemingly random reasons. So eh, I said  to myself why didn't I try to play by myself and review this thing?

A bit background info, I have never had any real Pool (IRL) experience except some fun games with friends, so I can't say from professional's point of view about how the physic or ball movement or rules work.

For this price point (approx 8-9 USD in my region), you get a pretty pool game graphic-wise, both offline and online experience, daily quest and the standard controller support, Steam Cloud + Achievements + Cards. Pretty much fair considering you can choose so many modes in addition like:

- You can play campaign/career mode against AI,
- Endurance mode where you try to slot in the balls faster than the game puts in your table,
- Free practice mode (9 balls, 8 balls etc) - recommended if you want to get a feel of the ball or shooting practice,
- Versus mode (hotseat) to play against your friend next to each others,
- Online mode

The control is nice and easy even for pure amateur like me. There's a tutorial to help you understand the game and AI is adjustable so you don't get smashed and fall into despair pit when you play the game for the first few hours.

Performance wise, I slide up everything to max and I still get silky smooth experience on my toaster-like laptop (5200u + 840m). There's an annoyingly long loading times every time you enter new match or load up the game but I'm sure it's fixable by adding up SSD for the game files (I'm using the good old SATA). The game doesn't give good impression when you alt+tab to do something else though, as it actively consumes your CPU's power. Not sure if this is Unity behavior or just the game being poorly optimized  in this regard, as another Unity game like Teslagrad sleeps just fine in background mode.

For the sound aspects, frankly my personal preference is to play this game without sound except the balls bouncing against each others, but the default in-game sound roster is not bad. Not memorable, but not bad. For this type of game it's the gameplay that matters most, but maybe it's just my personal taste.

Developers seem to take a good care of this game and put an effort into fixing things. I personally had crashes that I reported to them when playing but it looks like it got patched and my issue is now non existent. At least unlike many developers who abandon their game, this one doesn't look like one.

All in all, the game is ok - fun to play even for pool noob like me. I can't say this is the best pool game ever, as I haven't even played THAT many pool games, but yeah, it's a nice game to play.

reviewText:
This is a hard one to review as there are so many variables involved...
TLDR - Graphics: 10/10 | Controls: 9/10 | Audio: 4/10 | Gameplay: 9/10 | Developer Commitment: 10/10 | X-Factor: 2/10

This review is based on buying Full game with all DLC during Holiday Sale for ZAR100 / USD9

Graphics:
The visuals are awesome... definately can't fault anything here. (on 980GTX / 660GTX and 540M (Mobile)

Controls:
Controls are great. Reason for giving this a 9/10 is due to the 'console' generation of controls and GUI which could have been a lot easier to navigate through. Would still love to know how to access my 2 shot replays (lightening bolts) otherwise the rest of the controls are well documented.

Audio:
The audio quality is perfect but the reason for this being 4/10 is the limited midi instrumental soundtrack which gets a bit monotonous after a while and for me, personally, there is a female laugh which cycles every 10 seconds or so which also gets a bit grinding after while. These individual volumes are all adjustable and you can always run mediaplayer with your own beats.

Gameplay:
There is only so much the game of pool can really offer yet the developers have created heaps of different content from trickshots, multiplayer live matches to career mode. Personally, I will still play ocassionally with mates but doubt I would ever hit the 50 hour mark.

Developer Commitment:
To be honest, I have never seen a developer more involved in the 'Negative Review' community than Cherry Pop.
This however can also be their biggest problem.

X-Factor:
Where to start...
An over committed dev ('we listen to the community' style) has both positive and negative attributes.
Making this a F2P game was a mistake. It just doesn't fit the model of a successful F2P game.
Obviously this was adopted to increase the database of online players to counter-act complaints of 'servers are dead' by game purchasers. We all know that the development of a game costs ... yet for some reason its always the F2P that write all the negative reviews ... These should be labelled 'Demos'.

Would I purchase at this very moment 13/01/2016?
No probably not.

If you take the dev/community out of the equation, I would definately buy this game again without hesitation.
As of right now it seems the F2P version would be the better choice if you enjoy a casual game of pool.

Seems like the developers are pretty much unlocking everything besides online play in F2P version.
A positive is the fact that a F2P can access all the content when playing with a game purchaser.
I'm interested to see what transpires here wrt dev vs community interaction.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Is this game worth buying ? There's a short answer to that question: absolutely (with a few annotations regarding improvements).

First of all, the game is not hard to play if anyone is worried about that, as the controls are quite simple, yet sufficient for cueing with more precision. Truly anyone can learn to play pool with this game. Secondly, the graphics are beautiful (if your pc can handle the game at the maximum settings of course, although the system requirements aren't really demanding). The locations in which you're able to play are stunning and decorated in great detail to fully immerse you into the setting. There are numerous cues, ball sets and even decals to choose from (if unlocked through playing the game), wich give you the ability to personalise your game. Great lighting effects and realistic sounds add even more to this emuneration.

I need to mention, however, that there's still room for improvement. When the ball(s) have been cued the edges of the ball(s) seem to deform slightly when looked at from a (greater) distance. It may be due to anti-aliasing, I'm not sure about that. Besides, it would be great to have a few more camera angles to play with aside from the two that are currently available. The physics could be better as well, as it nearly seems as if the balls roll across a grass surface rather than a table. The balls seem to come to a halt too soon, but I might be wrong about that.

My overall opinion about this game is very positive, especially when you take the fact into consideration that the game is still in the alpha stage. Keep up the good work and try to fix the bugs and alterations I mentioned before, please :)

Early Access Review

Highly recommended. If you liked Pool Nation, this is that, with a new engine, better graphics, new music, additional snooker mode *that I know we wanted in the original*.

Some gripe that some features were promised in the original, I am not recalling that exact promise, but I know it was something to look for *in the future*, and here it is.
I think a updated release is well justified here, and I am quick to burn Devs for re-releasing without real progress, but I think this is real progress.
I *dispise* early access, and buy very few games that are early access. This game is a fully working game, with in progress development, and THAT is the right way to do early access, so Cherry Pop gets my money and approval.
On top of all this, both Pool Nation and Pool Nation FX are quality products with value pricetags. Nobody should be complaning on that level. Please keep up the good work Cherry Pop, and gloss over the sour notes of some, but do listen to valid concerns and suggestions.

Uses the same game engine as pool nation. So the play is fluid , Once you get used to the speed. The draw strength seems very low, and needs boosting a bit to make it to feel better.

Having to use overhead view on distance shots just kills the realism in the game. Ideally set up a point of view key so you can offset what you are looking at, Just like you do in real life.

Graphics support could use some tweaking. I was unable to set my native resolution 2560 X 1600. I ended up having to play in full screen, non windowed mode with 4k resolution. Which is not bad since pool games are not gpu intensive. I would rather play in my native resolution in windowed mode so I can view my second screen inbetween shots.

Overall for an early access game,  a good experience. The fixes are minor programming wise, with the exception of a better viewing angle. The only real bugs I saw was the graphics detail set up.
Looking foward to the full game in a more refined form.

Is it Virtual Pool 4? Not quite. But I don't think it's trying to be. Pool Nation FX finds a happy medium between simulator and casual game. Graphics-wise, it's wonderful. Pool Nation FX is a great effort by Cherry Pop. When compared to the abysmal Pure Pool, it's a no-brainer.

A well structured and easy to understand multiplayer game system.
I really can't fault it and I'm very happy to have stumbled across it :-)

reviewText:
I installed this game wanting to play 1v1 vs a friend... yeah that's not going to happen. The free version is VERY limited. It's basically just a demo where you can't do much but sample what the full game would be like. Theres a curency system in the game that lets you make a little money (around $2000 per day?) but honestly I'm not going to play for 5 days to unlock something when my initial experience is what it was.

As for the game itself, if you like playing pool video games this one looks really great. It shows where the path of the ball as well as the path of the ball that you hit... but this feature also some limitations:

1) It doesn't show the distance of the two very well.
2) If you bank the ball off the rail, it doesn't show the path for the ball you hit.
3) If the ball you hit hits another ball, that path isnt shown (so a break shot, which should have tons of paths, doesn't show much)
4) Making the ball move the way that you plan is nearly impossible since you have to hit it very precisely. Adding spin (side to side) and english (forward and backwords) is almost useless. If you know how it works you don't need it and if you don't you wont be able to pull it off every time.

Overall, the auto-aiming-path-thing tells you what you should already know and it doesn't help you learn how to do trickier shots. I've played it for about an hour and I'm probably going to uninstall it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A major step up from its predecessor, even in Early Access form.  Pool Nation FX introduces a more robust and challenging set of aiming mechanics, vastly improved graphics, and online competition.  It also features the triumphant return of Snooker, my personal favourite way to play pool.  Snooker has largely been ignored since the glory days of Virtual Snooker on Windows 95, and I'm glad Cherry Pop decided to feature it in this next installment.  I'm also glad to see some NPCs hanging around the venues to make things feel more realistic, instead of feeling like I'm stuck in someone's incomplete virtual reality program.  Still, they should be interacting more with the player.  I wouldn't mind some tournament backdrops with an audience.  Pool Nation FX sticks to the down and dirty basics of pool, but it needs some dynamic atmosphere to really make it come alive.  The music is better than the original, though nothing spectacular.  Who else wants a custom soundtrack option to be able to play pool with their own playlist?  Are you listening, Cherry Pop?

In Early Access form, I feel that some things could be refined, most notably the mouse aiming.  It can feel a little sluggish when lining up a shot, and I wouldn't mind being able to scroll back a bit more for a better view.  Does it kill the gameplay for me?  Absolutely not.  But I think the original control scheme was far more swift.  There are a lot of modes to play, tournaments to enter, and online bouts to keep you entered for hours.  Pool Nation was a step in the right direction towards becoming the world's foremost billiards simulator.  I want to see Cherry Pop perfect the FX version even more than they have.  No resting on laurels!  This is too good a foundation to pass up.

Early Access Review

TL;DR

If you liked pool nation, or just want a good pool game, this is a game for you!



Long version:

I really liked pool nation, but i had a few bad experiences with early access games, so it was a bit hard to buy this game, But i've found out pretty soon, that this game worth a buy. First of all it doesn't feels like an early access game.

+You can play snooker..... actually i don't like snooker, but still, you can enjoy that.
+The multiplayer is so much better. You can easily find/host/watch games.
+You can bet in game money when you are playing online, so it can spice up the games a lot. :D

Con:
-You have to reach a certain level, to play online without aiming ads. With aiming ads it's basically first mistake=lose so it's pretty boring. But once you reach lvl 20 (if i remember correctly) you can play without aiming ads. But still, i don't really understand this.
-Musics are bad.
